CARNEGIE ENDOWMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL PEACE
UNITED NATIONS PLAZA AT 46TH STREET
WEW YORK 17, NEW YORK
^ABLE ADDRESS INTERPAX
JUN 4 1958
2 June 1958
i
Dear Mr. Underwood:
Thank you for your kind letter of May 7th, agreeing to
consider our projected half hour radio program on the Carnegie Endow¬
ment's publication, Britain and the United Nations . We e3q)ect to record
a tape at United Nations Headquarters within the next two weeks. The
participants will be Sir Pierson Dixon, Permanent Representative to the
United Nations, Professor Allan Nevins, eminent historian and author,
Mr. Alex Faulkner, correspondent for the London Daily Telegraph and
Mr. William Stringer, correspondent for the Christian Science Monitor.
Professor Nevins will act as chairman of the discussion.
I quite understand that you cannot accept this program until you audition
it and we will naturally accept your judgement on this matter. We expect,
however, with United Nations assistance to maintain production and technical
standards in accordance with professional broadcast requirements.
The recording will be between 28’ and 28' 45" long. It will be recorded
at a speed of 15 IPS. If there are any other specifications, please inform me,
if possible, by return mail.
Thank you for your cooperation.
Sincerely yours,
Roger Lyons
Director of Public Relations
Mr. Robert E. Underwood,Jr.
Network Manager
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
University of Illinois
119 Gregory Hall
Urbana, Illinois
